Digital Summit 2020 speakers

Our presenters

We've carefully chosen presenters who will inspire and engage.

The Digital Summit is your opportunity to hear and learn from digital thought leaders about transforming government services at every level.

We would like to thank all our speakers and keynotes for their contributions to the Digital Summit.

We will update our presenters as we confirm them.

Master of Ceremonies and Welcome to Country

James O'Loghlin

Master of Ceremonies

James is one of Australia's most respected, entertaining and experienced corporate speakers and media personalities. He is best known as the host of over 300 episodes of 'The New Inventors' on ABC, and for his witty and entertaining programs on ABC Local Radio.

Paul House

Welcome to Country

Ngambri-Ngunnawal custodian

Paul is a Ngambri-Ngunnawal custodian and has multiple local Aboriginal ancestries from the Canberra Region, however identifies as a descendant of Ngambri-Walgulu man Henry 'Black Harry' Williams and Ngunnawal-Wallaballoa man William Lane, also known as 'Billy the Bull', born in the centre of his ancestral country, at the old Canberra Hospital. His mother, Dr Aunty Matilda House, has a long-established connection to Canberra and is recognised across the region for her leadership and representation on Indigenous issues.

Back to menu

Keynotes

The Hon Stuart Robert MP

Keynote

Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme and Minister for Government Services

Stuart is Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme and Minister for Government Services. He served in the Army for 12 years in Infantry and Intelligence Corps units including deploying operationally to Bougainville in 1998 as part of the Peace Monitoring Force. Whilst serving in the Army, he completed a Bachelor of Arts (Hons) and Masters' degrees in both Business Administration and Information Technology. After leaving the Army he and a colleague founded an IT services firm. He was elected Member for Fadden in 2007. He served as Shadow Defence Science, Technology and Personnel Minister, and became Assistant Minister for Defence in 2013. In 2015 he became Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Human Services and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Centenary of ANZAC.

Rebecca Skinner

Keynote

CEO, Services Australia

Rebecca is CEO of Services Australia, which is entering a time of transformation. She has a proven track record of crisis management as the former Associate Secretary of Defence during Australia's bushfire disasters in 2019 and 2020 and brings this critical capability to Services Australia. She has a wealth of experience in the public sector, working in strategic, enterprise planning and risk management roles, including at the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, and as a senior executive in the Attorney-General's Department.

Mr Peter Woolcott AO

Keynote

Commissioner, Australian Public Service Commission (APSC)

Peter became Australian Public Service Commissioner on 9 August 2018. Peter has had a distinguished career in the Australian Public Service, serving in senior diplomatic positions around the world. He has served as Australia's High Commissioner to New Zealand (2016–2017), Ambassador for the Environment (2014–2016), and led the negotiations to the Paris Agreement on climate change (2016), Permanent Representative to the UN in Geneva and Ambassador for Disarmament (2010–2014), Ambassador for People Smuggling Issues (2009), Ambassador to Italy (2004–2007), and Australian Consul-General, Honolulu and Representative to US Commander-in-Chief Pacific (1998–2001). Most recently he has served as former Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's Chief of Staff. Mr Woolcott was appointed an Officer in the Order of Australia in 2017 for his distinguished service to public administration in the field of international relations, and as a lead negotiator in the non-proliferation and arms control fields.

Randall Brugeaud

Keynote

CEO, Digital Transformation Agency

Randall was appointed Chief Executive Officer of the DTA on 1 July 2018. Randall has spent more than 30 years working in a range of public and private sector roles, with a focus on transformation. His public sector experience has spanned large, medium, and small organisations. Randall's private sector experience includes more than a decade working with the Boston Consulting Group and a private IT consulting firm, which he founded and operated. Before joining the DTA, Randall was Deputy Australian Statistician and Chief Operating Officer at the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Before that he was Chief Information Officer at the Department of Immigration and Border Protection. Randall holds a Master of Business Administration, a Graduate Diploma in Applied Computing and a Bachelor of Education. He is also a Senior Executive Fellow of the Harvard Kennedy School.

Back to menu

Speakers

Jim Grubb

Speaker

Chief Technology Evangelist, Cisco

As an expert in digitisation even before it was called digitisation, Jim has spent most of his career helping people understand how business and technology intersect. He is an exponential thinker and charismatic speaker currently working with most of Cisco's largest customers as they build their digital strategies. As former Cisco CEO John Chambers' long-time product-demo sidekick, he delivered over 400 keynote demonstrations at industry, technology, and CXO events, including Cisco Live, CES, HIMSS, NRF, Oracle World, Salesforce, DODIS, Cisco Partner Summit, and Cisco's World-wide Sales meetings. He has also presented to many Government and World Leaders, including Hillary Clinton, George W. Bush, Tony Blair, Madeleine Albright, Dimitry Medvedev, Al Gore, Viktor Chernomyrdin, Vicente Fox, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Jean Carnahan, and Jim Gilmore. When he's not explaining technology, he is an avid astrophotographer, musician, pilot, and boater.

Living in a digital world

Since the arrival of the vacuum tube, technology has significantly impacted how work gets done. Today's innovations continue to accelerate the pace of change. Simply, we are living in a digital world.

Jim explores:

  • how current technologies such as machine learning, artificial intelligence, robotics, virtual and augmented reality, voice and haptic user interfaces are making us more capable
  • how the Internet-of-Things and blockchain are combining with new levels of connectivity, including WiFi6, 5G, and low-Earth orbit satellite systems to allow us to re-invent the way we work.

Tom Burton

Speaker

Government Editor, Australian Financial Review (AFR)

Tom has held senior editorial and publishing roles with The Mandarin, The Sydney Morning Herald and is Canberra bureau chief for the Australian Financial Review. He has worked in government, specialising in communications. He has won 3 Walkley awards.

Service 4.0

Service 4.0 is a way for governments to reframe their large investments in service transformation into a strategy. This strategy can promote better services across Australian, robust ecosystem development and collaborative platform growth to drive new markets, investment, and jobs.

The key insight is that if we design in an open and collaborative way, digital transformation of services can open enormous opportunity.

Professor Beth Simone Noveck

Speaker

Director, The Governance Lab

Beth is a graduate of Harvard University and Yale Law School and directs Governance Lab (GovLab) and its MacArthur Research Network on Opening Governance. She is a Professor in Technology, Culture, and Society and affiliated faculty at the Center for Urban Science and Progress at New York University's Tandon School of Engineering and a Fellow at NYU's Institute for Public Knowledge. She was New York state's first Chief Innovation Officer and German Chancellor Angela Merkel named her to her Digital Council in 2018. She is also Visiting Senior Faculty Fellow at the John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University. Beth was the first United States Deputy Chief Technology Officer and director of the White House Open Government Initiative under President Obama. UK Prime Minister David Cameron appointed her senior advisor for Open Government. At GovLab, she directs better governance programs, including work the CrowdLaw, Smarter Crowdsourcing, and City Challenges programs. She also coaches 'public entrepreneurs', working with passionate individuals to take their public interest projects from idea to implementation. Beth is the author of Smart Citizens, Smarter State: The Technologies of Expertise and the Future of Governing and Wiki Government: How Technology Can Make Government Better, Democracy Stronger and Citizens More Powerful. She co-edited The State of Play: Law, Games and Virtual Worlds.

Ernez Dhondy

Speaker

General Manager, Paper Giant

With 15 years of experience in the industry, Ernez has established himself as an experienced design leader. Over the course of his career, Ernez has integrated and established design practices in some of Australia's largest digital and full-service agencies. He has mentored emerging design talent and a new generation of design leaders. He has led large-scale digital strategy and transformation programs across the public, private and social sectors. He has a deep understanding of these sectors and is passionate about helping clients experiment with new ways of working to generate new types of value. Ernez has worked across continents and been an active contributor to the digital culture in Australia across his entire career.

Can we co-create our way out of this?

COVID-19 has changed the way government, communities, and organisations work. It is the greatest societal change we are likely to experience, and we need to equip our organisations to deal with it. The pandemic didn't come with a playbook, strategic framework, or case study to help us navigate our way through it.

But we do have a starting point. I believe co-design is the most useful tool we have to help decision-makers through this crisis. It is a deeply human, community-based approach that can help government transform the way it delivers products and services to better meet the evolving needs of citizens. We can use co-design to leverage the thoughts, feelings, and intuitions at the coal face of this crisis. It can solve many of the issues the government currently faces and only through true participatory collaboration can we forge the best pathway out of this crisis.

I have recently completed work on a co-design project aimed at understanding and reacting to the needs of Australians experiencing mental health and wellbeing difficulties during COVID-19. The project produced more than just products and service concepts. It allowed leaders to work in partnership with individuals to fundamentally shift the strategic direction of the organisation.

Stephen Scheeler

Speaker

Founder, Digital CEO

The world has gone digital, but Australian business risk falling behind. As advisor, mentor and speaker, Stephen partners with Australia's business leaders to help them master digital strategy, culture, and leadership, and build innovative, global, billion-dollar businesses. He has spoken at TEDx, the Australian Governance Summit and AMP Amplify. He is a member of the Prime Minister's Knowledge Nation 100 top innovation leaders in Australia. His career spans over 25 years across consumer products, retail, ecommerce, automotive, financial services, media, and technology. He has served in senior executive roles at global leaders Westfield and Inchcape, and at Australian consumer products giant Lion. He guided Facebook's rise from Silicon Valley start-up to media and technology titan as CEO for Australia and New Zealand.

Leadership in a digital age: how today's leaders must change to succeed in a digital age

Until now, most business leaders have been able to build successful careers without deep digital chops. For decades, strong command or financial, operational, or technical disciplines were the bedrock of business leadership, and 'digital' was left to others in the organisation to understand and apply.

In the future, digital experience and skills will mean the difference between success and failure in leading businesses of all sizes and sectors...and will be the #1 determinant of weather you get that next job, or someone more digital beats you to it.

Stephen Scheeler shares his personal journey of digital leadership as Facebook CEO for Australia and New Zealand, and distils important and practical advice for business leaders of all stripes – from small business entrepreneurs to Fortune 500 CEOs and board directors – on how to 'digitise' their personal leadership style, rapidly gain impressive digital experience and insight, and remake themselves into versatile, high-impact, digital savvy leaders.

Fiona Hathaway

Speaker

Managing Director, Global People Team, Slalom

Fiona Hathaway is the Managing Director for the Global People Team at Slalom Consulting. Her international career spanned Asia, Europe, and the US, and in HR in IT companies like KPMG and PWC. In her global HR Director role at Microsoft, she drove several large-scale global business transformations. Her current challenges are working to drive global expansion into new markets while implementing modern work practices and ways of working which will support high paced growth through digitalisation and innovation.

Dr Catherine Ball

Speaker

Scientific Futurist, World of Drones and Robotics/Australian National University

Dr Catherine Ball is an author, founder, and ethics advocate working across global projects where robotics and new technology meet environmental protection. A sought-after voice in industry, Catherine's biggest passion is on projects that have a humanitarian aspect, ranging from the use of RPAS for emergency response, to recording cultural heritage, and agricultural assessments. Catherine has travelled and worked globally on cutting edge projects that combine science, entrepreneurship, empowerment, education, and training.

Industry 5.0: Humankind over the horizon

Technological literacy is a human right. There are some game-changing innovations and exponential technologies racing towards us. We deserve the best that they bring; and we should know how to identify, interrogate, and challenge the assumptions and biases that may be inherent within them. Learn more about how the future is more human, and how robotics, technology, AI, and data will fuel the next industrial revolution.

Jonathon Thorpe

Speaker

General Manager, Digital Identity and myGov, Digital Transformation Agency

Jonathon is the General Manager for Digital Identity and myGov at the DTA. He has extensive public sector experience working across large service delivery agencies with over 10 years in executive roles. He has delivered large-scale initiatives across digital marketing, social media, customer experience (CX), staff experience, and whole-of-government transformation domains. Jonathon is incredibly passionate about CX, agile leadership, and applying digital to radically improve how government services are delivered.

Panel: A global perspective on Digital Identity

Digital identity is one of the most significant technology trends in the world, for governments, their citizens and the private sector. The number of digital identity schemes offered by governments and the private sector has proliferated over the past five years, and is expected to grow exponentially as the United Nation's push for 'legal identity for all, by 2030' gathers pace.

In this panel, Australian and international digital identity leaders will:

  • Compare successful models of national digital identity schemes.
  • Identify the critical elements need to build public trust and drive adoption.
  • Discuss the benefits from international interoperability.

Quek Sin Kwok

Speaker

Senior Director, National Digital Identity Programme (NDI) Government Technology Agency (GovTech)

Quek Sin oversees the National Digital Identity Programme, one of Singapore's 5 Strategic National Projects announced in 2017. The National Digital Identity will be a nationally-available way for an individual to prove their legal identity online. It is also a platform for the public and private sectors to build more digital services on a common and universal trust framework for identity, authentication, consent, authorisation, digital signatures, eKYC and data platforms. Quek Sin and his team look forward to collaborating closely with government agencies, industry partners and the international community to develop the necessary ecosystems which can enable online trust, transform user journeys and streamline operations. Before joining the Public Service in 2009, Quek Sin served in multiple consulting and management roles across various MNCs, including Accenture, Deloitte Consulting and HP.

Quek Sin is a panel member for 'A global perspective on Digital Identity.'

Alan Bell

Speaker

Executive Director, Digital Identity at Department of Internal Affairs, New Zealand

Alan is an experienced strategist in government digital in New Zealand, and a senior leader in the office of the Government Chief Digital Officer. His previous roles include leading the development of New Zealand's first Cyber Security Strategy, developing the government's cloud computing policy and policy lead for New Zealand's ICT Strategy. He is currently leading a NZ Digital Identity Transition Program.

Alan is a panel member for 'A global perspective on Digital Identity.'

Margo Stephen

Speaker

Head of Digital iD, Australia Post

Margo leads Australia Post's Digital iD business. She has is responsible for market growth, strategy and development. Digital iD is an award-winning, innovative, secure, smart-phone based way for individuals to easily prove who they are online and in-person, and for business and government to identify their customers. Margo has over 20 years' experience in consulting, strategy and delivery and has led numerous large-scale business and technology transformation programmes in Australia and the UK.

Margo is a panel member for 'A global perspective on Digital Identity.'

Back to menu

Workshop presenters

Lana Thorpe

Workshop

Director, Customer Strategy and Experience Design, Deloitte Digital

Lana is a Director in the Customer Strategy and Experience Design team at Deloitte Digital. With over 13 years of industry experience across both public and private sectors, Lana specialises in human-centred, service, and strategic design, agile delivery, and experience visioning.

Experimental futures: designing a prosperous nation

The global pandemic has drastically accelerated transformation and our perceptions of what's possible. Futurists, designers, change-makers and leaders are eager to take advantage of the shifting economic and social landscape to design better futures. We invite you to explore the current drivers and mega-shifts, to design new world scenarios for the future of government. Experimental futures provide us with new tools, methods and frameworks to make sense of this complexity and to understand emerging risks and opportunities to better inform the actions we take today.

We've designed this session to empower organisations to consider the future in their decision-making. They can explore a variety of scenarios to solve emerging problems in novel ways to reveal insights into effective actions towards desirable futures. We will introduce participants to a range of futures and scenario-planning methods in a practical setting with a focus on the human services, transport, and education sectors. We also provide an Experimental Futures Playbook for all participants to help bridge learning-to-doing to extend learning beyond the virtual classroom.

Francois Kirsten

Workshop

Manager, Customer Strategy and Design, Deloitte Digital

Francois is a Strategic Designer at Deloitte Digital. He is driven by a desire to tackle wicked problems like overpopulation, the future of work, and climate change. He is passionate about the design of modern business and looks for solutions that balance profit and prosperity for people and the planet in uncertain times.

Francois is co-presenter for 'Experimental futures: designing a prosperous nation'.

Darren Menachemson

Workshop

Thinkplace Partner, Chief Digital Officer and Chief Ethicist

As designer and ethicist, Darren works to tackle large-scale societal challenges in Australia and around the world. He is a global partner with ThinkPlace and serves as Chief Ethicist and Chief for Digital Societies. He is a board member of ThinkAction, Johns Hopkins University's human-centred design partner for USAID's international Breakthrough Action program and is co-founder and Chief Impact Officer of the Ed Institute, which works to create and inspire the next generation of changemakers. He spent a decade in the Australian Public Service, establishing and leading strategic design and transformation capabilities. He has worked on Australia's largest digital transformation initiatives and has trained hundreds of senior executives in digital transformation leadership and digital ethics. Darren believes that Australian society is in a profound digital transition and that the APS will be a critical precedent-setter for ethical impact.

55 minutes in the digital ethics pressure cooker

It's 2025. Sustainability is at the top of the world's agenda, and Australia is conducting a bold policy experiment that rewards households consuming sustainably, through the tax system.

You will assume the role of a Digital Ethics Analyst, and work with a small team of peers to reflect on a particularly controversial aspect of the policy design. Your job is to confront a difficult digital ethics dilemma and think through the digital ethics implications.

We will introduce you to important ethics concepts and a digital ethics framework that can guide your thinking. But make no mistake: it will not be clear cut, and it will not feel comfortable.

The course is suited to those currently or potentially involved in digital transformation programs, with a decision-making, design or assurance role. You do not need prior knowledge of digital ethics or ethics theory.

This will debut a new workshop from ThinkPlace. Thinkplace have a strong track record of running inspiring and energising Pressure Cooker sessions where participants take on a realistic digital or policy ethics challenge.

Zoe Rose

Workshop

UX Designer and Trainer, Synergy

Zoe works in user experience design, information architecture, content design, and educational technologies. Zoe's career has spanned the UK and Australia. She has worked for the BBC, Cambridge University Press, GOV.UK, PwC and Seek. She has presented widely on disability topics, including at UX Australia. Her interest in the relationship between disability and design has deep roots. She acquired a serious disability after a fall in 2018. This experience deepened her commitment to talking about disability and the benefits designing for disability can bring to people who build and maintain services as widely as possible, especially in government.

Solve for one, extend to many: a practical hypothetical exercise in inclusive design for people with disabilities

Disability is an under-valued element of human diversity that is insufficiently understood in technology. The principles and benefits of inclusive design are now well established. But how can they be applied in government? In this workshop, participants will undertake some structured activities before engaging in a collaborative design challenge. This workshop is hypothetical. We will not conduct user research with a disabled person, we will engage with a persona.

Jane Cipants

Workshop

Director, Client Service, Legal Aid NSW

Jane has spent over 20 years in the legal assistance sector in management, service design and delivery. Previously she was a social worker in the mental health sector. Jane holds a Bachelor of Social Work and Masters' degrees in social policy and public administration.

Digital design and disadvantaged clients: bringing voices at the margins to the centre of digital service design and delivery

Our Legal Aid NSW Strategic Plan places clients at the centre of everything we do. Through our digital work program, we co-designed the development of digital tools with highly disadvantaged clients who considered themselves digitally excluded and had challenges engaging with government services. We brought their voice to every step of the design process to improve their experience of getting help.

Our clients are often marginalised. Being part of these projects empowered them and made sure their voices were heard and needs met. For many, it was the first time an 'institution' had asked their opinion and encouraged them to share the expertise of their lived experience.

The global COVID-19 pandemic did not prevent us from engaging and designing with our clients. We share how to recruit and engage with clients online in a virtual context to maximise their input and engagement.

Judith Levitan

Workshop

Manager, Client Service, Legal Aid NSW

Judith has worked in the public legal assistance sector for over 15 years. Previously she was a lawyer in a private practice. She has degrees in law and social work. In her latest role she brings the voice of the client into the strategic conversation about how Legal Aid NSW designs and delivers services.

Judith is co-presenter for 'Digital design and disadvantaged clients: bringing voices at the margins to the centre of digital service design and delivery'.

Julian Smith

Workshop

Agile Lead, Digital Transformation Agency (DTA)

Julian Smith is the Head of the Agile practice at the DTA and is a certified trainer, coach, and practitioner. He has worked in digital ICT for over 20 years, including roles in project and product management, agile and project management offices, digital strategy, enterprise architecture, and user experience. He is passionate about public sector agility and the benefits it provides agencies in Australia and the world. He was a member of the DTA's first UX working group and other committees. Today he works with agencies, helping to build capability in digital ways of working He has an interest in strategic agility, adaptive portfolio management and enabling digital culture change.

Agility accelerator

Today 'agile' is no longer just a buzzword. From building spacecraft to manufacturing, some of the most complex and largest organisations in the world are using agile ways of working to deliver better outcomes, respond to change, improve quality, foster more productive and happier teams, and reduce risk.

This hands-on and interactive session is aimed at helping public sector organisations build capability to support agile ways of working, from policy development through to service design and delivery.

Participants will have access to resources and materials to help accelerate capability building within their own organisations.

Craig Smith

Workshop

Agilist, SoftED

Craig Smith has been an agile practitioner, coach and one of Australia's premier agile trainers for over 15 years. He is one of Australia's biggest contributors to the agile community. He is the Global Agility Lead for SoftEd, a director of the Agile Alliance, co-organiser of the Agile Brisbane Meetup Group, co-host of one of the world's leading agile podcasts, and an agile editor for InfoQ. He has comprehensive experience at government agencies and specialises in all facets of agile training, executive coaching, and technical excellence by helping teams and organisations improve their quality.

Craig is co-presenter for 'Agility accelerator'.

Anthony McGinness

Workshop

Policy Design Director, Future Friendly

Anthony is Future Friendly's Policy Design Director and leads their Canberra studio where they partner with government to find ways to move forward with complex projects with greater confidence. He developed his experience in citizen-centric policy and service design over many years working across Commonwealth, state and territory, local government and not-for-profits. This experience ranges from applying design thinking to shape more responsive youth justice and family and domestic violence policies, to user research and program management as part of major digital transformation projects. Before he joined Future Friendly he worked as a senior executive in a strategic management consulting firm for over a decade. He is passionate about social justice and has been an Indigenous Community Volunteer for over a decade. He is privliged to have volunteered on numerous community-driven projects in communities such as the Torres Strait, Aputula, Alice Springs and Condobolin.

The team retro: reflecting on working from home

There is no playbook for what we are experiencing. Our teams have had to adapt to a new normal overnight. At Future Friendly, we have been running regular team retros since the pandemic began. This has enabled us to adapt and adjust as a team and promoted transparency and trust among leadership and staff. We have charted team sentiment moving from anxiety in uncertainty, to enjoying the silver linings of working from home, to video call fatigue and a desire to reconnect in person.

We want to share the benefits of the team retro. The session will draw on lessons documented in our remote team guide https://acceleration.team/, and encourage participants to engage in an abridged live team retro, individually carding up and playing back their own reflections on what has and hasn't worked well for them.

Saakshi Joshi

Workshop

Lead Organisational Designer, Future Friendly

Saakshi is a Design Lead for Future Friendly's organisational design offering, working with leaders and teams to co-create change in their organisations. Her focus is to build more connected, adaptive, and effective teams.

Saakshi is co-presenter for 'The team retro: reflecting on working from home'.

Back to menu

Case study presenters

Leon Young

Case Study

Cogniss

Leon's creative digital career spans over 20 years across education, advertising and marketing, behaviour change and games. His work in health and educational technology has been recognised internationally, with the team he leads winning over 50 major awards in the USA, UK, and Australia.

How human transformation technology is empowering governments and service providers to deliver rapid mobile mental health responses during COVID-19

To address the burden on health workers' mental health during COVID-19, leaders in technology and clinical care collaborated to deliver The Essential Network, an Australian government-funded mobile app providing specialist mental health advice and triaged support.

The solution is technologically innovative in two ways. The app was developed on Cogniss, an Application Platform as a Service (APaaS) for creating Human Transformation Technology (HTT) solutions. HTT applies behavioural science to product design to help users achieve better health outcomes. Additionally, a no-code approach allowed the initial version of the app to be co-designed, developed and ready for release in two weeks.

Anna Goldfeder

Case Study

Cogniss

Anna leads the end-to-end product design, development, and implementation of the Cogniss platform. Before she joined Cogniss in 2016, she spent 7 years designing, building and managing award-winning educational games, assessment platforms and core curriculum resources with leading secondary publisher Jacaranda (Wiley).

Anna is co-presenter for 'How human transformation technology is empowering governments and service providers to deliver rapid mobile mental health responses during COVID-19'.

Vi Nguyen

Case Study

KPMG

Vi has over 17 years' experience as a software engineer, digital strategist and innovator at Macquarie Bank, Volvo Cars, Swedish Space Association, and start-ups. She has led high-profile digital transformations and designing future labs in Australia, Asia and Sweden. She has been described as an 'entrepreneur at heart, with a heart'.

Designing services: a Swedish perspective

After spending 3 years within service and business design in Sweden, the purpose of this presentation is to provide an insight into how service design is applied in Sweden, how this differs from Australia and what we could possibly adopt to fast track designing for a human-centred government. I would like to impart some of my observations, whilst they are still 'fresh' to start the discussion and possibly generate new ideas.

Neil King

Case Study

Vision Australia

Neil has worked with a vast number of organisations in Europe and Australasia promoting and delivering inclusive outcomes. Currently leading Vision Australia's Digital Access team, government and commercial organisations draw on his expertise to go beyond compliance and deliver truly inclusive products.

Push and pull: why South Australia leads the way in online accessibility

As a result of new legislation introduced in 2018, the South Australian Government's Department of the Premier and Cabinet partnered with Vision Australia to develop a new approach to online accessibility.

South Australian Government's Online Accessibility Policy, Toolkit (accessibility.sa.gov.au) and supporting solutions are now co-designed with leading accessibility specialists, government, the community, not-for-profit organisations, the private sector and people with disability to ensure they have a leading role in shaping policies and creating programs which influence their lives.

Check out the journey, development and next steps: Push and pull: Why South Australia leads the way in online accessibility.

Nick Condon

Case Study

South Australian Government

As Head of Digital Citizen Services, Nick is responsible for the whole-of-government digital strategy required to deliver service transformation for the South Australian Government. He has a specific focus on improving or creating new digital services for all citizens of South Australia.

Nick is co-presenter for 'Push and pull: why South Australia leads the way in online accessibility'.

Tom Hacon

Workshop

Hypothesis

Tom works at the intersection of physical and digital, blending originality with persistence to deliver valuable experiences to his customers. He believes in having passion, autonomy, mastery, and purpose. He is currently Principal Product Owner at Service New South Wales.

How one team rapidly delivered drought, bushfire and COVID-19 crisis support to NSW citizens

Faced with the drought, bushfires, and COVID-19, the NSW State Government needed to rapidly support affected citizens.

This case study talks to how a persistent cross functional team in Service NSW were able to really understand what citizens really needed and come back to home base to deliver it in weeks (not months). The case study is backed by how the work happened, calling out specifically:

  • Human-centred design in the field not from the desk
  • Lean-agile development – practice not theory
  • Extreme Programming – pairing to build capability in Service NSW

Simon Goodrich

Case study

Portable

Simon is co-founder of Portable, a design company based in Melbourne. Portable responds to social need and policy failure and puts users in the centre. He has led the company's work in legal innovation since 2012. He is a Fellow at the Sir Zelman Cowan Centre at Victoria University, and a Teaching Fellow at Melbourne Law Scool teaching in Design for Innovation.

amica.gov.au – a digital solution for separating couples

Portable and National Legal Aid have recently launched amica.gov.au - a tool to help couples separate without the need for a lawyer. It leverages co-design, intuitive content and artificial intelligence to help people resolve their dispute themselves. This has resulted from 3 years user testing and agile development. Since being launched by the Federal Attorney-General on June 30 2020, over 1000 people have started this process, with agreements already being made between parties. Amica is an initiative of Portable that aligns with its mission to provide government services that meet and exceed the expectations of citizens.

Luke Thomas

Case study

Portable

Luke is Senior Legal Designer at Portable, working across legal design and technology products. He led the user research for Amica and worked to simplify the existing government processes as well as supported the data team on creating machine learning model to provide guidance for separating couples. He holds a Juris Doctor from Melbourne Law School.

Luke is co-presenter for 'amica.gov.au – a digital solution for separating couples'.

Tanya Newhouse

Case study

Clevertar

Tanya has 10 years senior management experience in health and human services, 7 years in early-stage technology commercialisation and 5 years in enterprise information technology management. She leads the executive team and market development for the Clevertar.mentation team, delivering outstanding results for customers.

From overwhelmed phone lines to SA Health's first virtual employee. How we built virtual agent Zoe in 6 days to respond to COVID-19

Designed by Clevertar and SA Health's team, we built and launched Zoe in 6 days to help SA Health respond to a surge in COVID-19-related questions to the state's hospital switchboards and contact lines.

At a time when demand for health-related information has increased exponentially, Zoe is working around-the-clock to answer questions and help South Australians follow official health guidelines.

The COVID-19 situation is changing rapidly with new information coming to light on a daily basis. Since its launch, Clevertar has been able to re-train Zoe and deploy new conversations in a matter of days.

Matt Francis

Case study

Solutions Lead, Clevertar

Matt is co-presenter for 'From overwhelmed phone lines to SA Health's first virtual employee. How we built virtual agent Zoe in 6 days to respond to COVID-19'.

Deb Anton

Case study

Interim National Data Commissioner

How the new Data Availability and Transparency legislation will drive innovation, growth and social wellbeing

On-demand presenters

John Cox

On-demand

Executive General Manager – Transformation & Enablement, Australia Post

John is EGM Transformation and Enablement Australia Post. He is responsible for evolving Australia Post's Transformation Strategy in the face of sustainability pressures and a need to rapidly pivot operations due to COVID-19. His career has covered the financial services such as banking, payments, insurance, wealth and markets, retail, government services and logistics.

Customer transformation – putting the customer at the heart of Australia Post's digital transformation

Australia Post has seen unprecedented parcel volumes throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, and experienced significant disruption across our operational network. We have relied heavily on technology solutions and real-time data insights to quickly identify and respond to challenges to make sure we continue meet the needs of our customers and the broader community.

The pandemic has reinforced our position that the customer experience must be at the heart of Australia Post's transformation. We strive to create simple and flexible experiences which delight our customers, and this principle is shaping our future network design and technology landscape.

Sarah Coye

On-demand

Head of Innovation, Royal Australian Mint

Sarah started her career in the health care sector. As a strong advocate for human-centred design, she created models of care that improved patient outcomes and experience. She applies these human-centred design and innovation frameworks to the APS to encourage disruption by challenging what no longer works and making sure the solutions are fit for purpose.

Innovation throughout a pandemic – empowering staff through times of adversity

COVID-19 changed how we work overnight, one moment I was preparing for my innovation strategic plan and the next it was turned inside-out and flipped on its head.

Remote engagement is hard, engagement when staff were a mix of onsite, working from home...is near impossible.

Using human-centred design, flexible working practices and good old fashion hard work, I created an innovation eco-system that allowed our staff to re-write the future of our organisation.

Come with me as I walk through our journey, challenging why we exist, how we might exist in the future and leveraging what makes us unique to catapult us into the future of the Royal Australian Mint.

Lucy Poole

On-demand

Digital Taskforce Lead, Digital Transformation Agency (DTA)

Lucy is passionate about driving positive change, delivering measurable outcomes, and continually improving government. Lucy leads the Sourcing and Enabling Division at the DTA. She focuses on providing whole-of-government strategic leadership to make digital procurement simple, clear, and fast.

Australia.gov.au – COVID-19 crisis response

On 17 March, there were 453 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Australia – more than double what it had been only 3 days earlier. With a national emergency on the horizon, the Australian Government needed a communications channel to deliver clear and consistent messages.

The DTA worked closely with PM&C to deliver the communications platform, with Deloitte Digital as our primary partner. With a team of over 40 people working remotely, we leveraged rapid prototyping design methodologies and strong cross-agency collaboration to build and launch a new australia.gov.au COVID-19 crisis homepage in under 6 hours.

Cecelia Hill

On-demand

Delivery Lead, Deloitte

Cecilia has built and led customer experience (CX) teams in organisations, developing an in-depth knowledge of applying design to strategic challenges, innovation, CX and product design. She is passionate about helping the public sector design and deliver citizen experiences that make interacting with government easy, smart, and personalised.

Cecelia is co-presenter for 'Australia.gov.au – COVID-19 crisis response'.

Dana Robertson

On-demand

Assistant Secretary, Communications, Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet

Dana is the Assistant Secretary of Communications in the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. She manages a team working across digital communication, media, strategic, corporate, and internal communications, speechwriting, and audio-visual production. She was closely involved in establishing Australian Government communication and whole-of-government coordination during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Dana is co-presenter for 'Australia.gov.au – COVID-19 crisis response'.

Millie Clery

On-demand

Millie is a creative design specialist who works with government to provide advice and guide development teams to create intelligent digital solutions. Leading the Digital Channels practice at NTT, she has a passion for solving complex problems through a user-centred design approach to make a positive change in people's lives.

Checking it twice: digital transformation of the naughty and nice list with the Department of Christmas Affairs

In the lead-up to Christmas 2019, the newly established Department of Christmas Affairs (DCA) quickly needed a user-centred website. With looming deadlines and budgetary pressure, the DCA embarked on a rapid design journey which saw the launch of www.christmasaffairs.com on 4 December 2019.

Designing and delivering the website was a rollercoaster of setbacks and successes, tragedies and triumphs, heartbreak, and happiness. But by following the DTA's Service Design and Delivery process, the DCA's vision was realised. www.christmasaffairs.com had over 250,000 unique visitors in the 4-week lead-up to Christmas. It was featured in ABC National News, the Canberra Times, Her Canberra, and over 100 syndicated news channels across the USA. It also blew up on social media.

While the DCA is not a real government department, the website is real and there are real learnings to share. This presentation provides practical advice on how to (and how not to) design a user-friendly website.

The presentation will appeal to product owners, UX designers, and content designers. Anyone working in website design and delivery will leave this presentation with some easy-to-implement tips and tricks to improve their own processes.

Clayton Smith

On-demand

Clayton is a senior user experience and content design consultant at NTT. He has worked on digital transformation projects for the Department of Health, the Department of Agriculture, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. He also teaches service design at the University of Canberra.

Clayton is co-presenter for 'Checking it twice: digital transformation of the naughty and nice list with the Department of Christmas Affairs'.

Garrett Tyler-Parker

On-demand

Pollinate Research

Clayton is a senior user experience and content design consultant at NTT. He has worked on digital transformation projects for the Department of Health, the Department of Agriculture, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. He also teaches service design at the University of Canberra.

How systems thinking can enhance your design thinking

Garrett is the Canberra Managing Director of Pollinate Research, an independent market and social research company. With research experience in Australia and South-East Asia, and experience in Parliament House's Federal Press Gallery, Garrett brings a well-rounded, real-world perspective to research, incorporating human behaviour and systems thinking, delivering actionable results.

Andrew Arch

On-demand

Intopia

Clayton is a senior user experience and content design consultant at NTT. He has worked on digital transformation projects for the Department of Health, the Department of Agriculture, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. He also teaches service design at the University of Canberra.

Accessibility considerations for ICT procurement – ensuring staff and citizens can use the systems government buys, adapts or builds

Andrew Arch is a Principal Consultant with Intopia and has been working in the field of digital accessibility for over 20 years. During this time, he established the digital access team at Vision Australia, worked on ageing and disability at the W3C in Europe and as the senior accessibility and inclusion expert in the Australian Government, including at the Digital Transformation Agency. Andrew is also a long-term participant in the Education and Outreach Working Group of the W3C Web Accessibility Initiative and Chairs the ICT Accessibility Committee at Standards Australia.

Sarah Pulis

On-demand

Intopia

Sarah is Director and Co-Founder of Intopia and can't compete with Andrew's years of experience (10 years isn't bad though, right?). She founded Intopia 4 years ago after working with PwC Australia and Media Access Australia. She also participates in the Education Outreach Working Group of the W3C Web Accessibility Initiative. She is the founder of A11y Bytes and A11Y Camp, which have grown to be Australia's largest events on digital accessibility and inclusion.

Sarah is co-presenter for 'Accessibility considerations for ICT procurement – ensuring staff and citizens can use the systems government buys, adapts or builds'.

Steph Waddon

On-demand

PwC

Steph is a HR expert with global experience in designing and implementing enterprise workforce solutions. She specialises in providing HR solutions to government clients in Canberra and serves as the ACT State President for the Australian Human Resources Industry and is a Fellow Certified Practitioner Human Resources (FCPHR).

The future of work is here

We will provide an overview of trends in the future of work, and how they could impact digital transformation within the public sector. The discussion will include an overview of the key workforce disruptors, the impacts of automation, social and demographic change, shifts in resourcing models and structures, and demand for different skills. We will use which our PwC case study examples to demonstrate these.

We will present a pragmatic approach to tackling future of work challenges and provide insights on our methodology.

Ben Neal

On-demand

PwC

Ben is a Fellow of the Australian Human Resources Institute and the UK-based Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development. He holds postgraduate HR and business qualifications with more than 20 years' experience working in government. Before joining PwC, he led the corporate and HR functions at the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Immigration.

Ben is co-presenter for 'The future of work is here'.

Harold Petersen

On-demand

Fresh Tracks Digital Consulting

Harold is a management consultant and transformation manager. He specialises in ICT strategy and governance, digital strategy, devops, SIAM, P3M, and organisational change.

Devops, Lean IT and agile: theory is one thing ... but what about the people?

This presentation introduces how the establishment of an organisational target capability is a holistic combination of multiple dimensions, and how people are a critical enabler. It demonstrates how leadership needs to drive the holistic alignment across all dimensions. It provides inspiration, insights and ideas on some ways to uplift people's capabilities around agile, lean and devops, and online collaboration.

Prof. Mal Thatcher

On-demand

Queensland University of Technology (QUT)

Mal is Professor of Digital Practice in the QUT Graduate School of Business. He is a career technologist and has held senior executive leadership positions in the public-sector and the private sectors. He has over 35 years' experience leading and delivering business value through technology-led innovation and transformation. Between 2004 and 2017 he held CIO roles in public and private sector organisations including Queensland Health, eHealth Queensland, and the Mater Hospital Group. He holds an Honours Degree in Computer Science, a Masters' in Applied Science and a PhD in Digital Risk and Governance. He has also completed a certificate program in IT Leadership from Harvard University.

Digital governance – what it is and why it is critical to the future of digital government

This presentation will focus on the importance of digital governance as agencies progress their digital transformation agendas. Governance controls are critical to address risks that emerge throughout the digital investment life cycle. This presentation will describe contemporary principles of digital governance through the lens of digital investment life cycle risk and provide practical advice regarding the key governance controls essential to successful digital investment. The presentation will also overview a case study on failed digital investment in the public sector in Queensland and speak to the key independent findings as they relate to a failure in governance.

According to a 2019 report from Forbes, 70% of digital transformation programs fail to meet their stated objectives. Understanding and dealing with transformation risk is critical to success; yet few organisations do it well, mostly because they do not understand the risks due to a lack of competency in digital projects and digital business. Digital governance is a key competency for senior manager and executives as we move towards digital government.

Dr Kerstin Oberprieler

On-demand

Co-Founder and Chief Executive Officer, Pentaquest

Kerstin is a leading gamification expert, having recently completed her PhD in gamification. She is a sought-after speaker and presenter in Australia and internationally. Before pursuing her passion for gamification, she worked as a design thinking consultant for 7 years, with a focus on strategic design, user research, and digital design. With her background in psychology and commerce, Kerstin has a deep understanding of organisational challenges and goals, and how these can be addressed through individual and team motivation. She has also spoken on the TEDx stage about the power of gamification.

How to use behavioural science and digital experience to increase employee engagement and organisational transformation

Behavioural science is the scientific revolution of our day. Never before has there been such a focus on human behaviour and decision making to address the critical challenges we face as a society. This is especially true for workplaces, which are experiencing a massive shift in how they operate, employee expectations, and digitally enabled collaboration. Behavioural sciences offer a new approach to dealing with the complexity of the workplace, by focussing in on human behaviour and dynamics. This behavioural lens is key to understanding and shifting engagement, performance and culture.

Sean McClowry

On-demand

Deloitte Digital

Sean is a partner in Deloitte Digital where he leads the Optimal Reality offering. Before Deloitte, Sean consulted with clients globally across digital and analytics. He was Head of Digital and CIO for an NGO, building information exchange platforms for climate change solutions. Sean has founded multiple web ventures and is the author of a book on information theory called Information Development.

Airservices Optimal Reality – digital twin of the skies

The aviation industry is entering the most disruptive decade since the first powered flight. Airservices Australia is investing to be ready.

Deloitte Digital and Airservices Australia developed a digital twin of Australian airspace that ingests live flight data and simulates forward faster than real time. It simulates thousands of possible outcomes every minute, optimising to the best one. Initial results indicate significant operational benefits and a transformation in how they innovate and deliver for the future.

Bringing Formula 1 thinking, human-centred design, and cutting-edge technology the team created an accurate, performant digital twin and a range of customer-centric apps to improve decision-making across the industry.

Michael Snell

On-demand

Airservices Australia

Mick has experience in aviation, network management and transformational change leadership. He brings these disciplines together to explore new paths and create connections for a rapidly transforming aviation industry. In driving digital transformation, he is a an enterprise-wide change agent, encouraging innovations leading to new information products and services and delivering technology capabilities in new ways.

Michael is co-presenter for 'Airservices Optimal Reality – digital twin of the skies'.

Adam Miesiwicz

On-demand

ASG Group

Adam is Regional Capability Manager, ACT, and National Capability Manager for Security at ASG Group. He has 15 years' experience in the federal government and private sectors, working in analytical, liaison, operational and advisory roles, as well as with leading private firms.

Cybersecurity – increasing cyber resilience above and beyond administrative compliance in 2020

The session will cover a range of highly relevant security topics for government departments. This includes the importance of overarching secure cloud and the successful implementation of risk mitigation strategies and focus on the issues and complexities involved with successfully passing audits and delivering projects and transformations of this nature. The session will also more deeply go beyond becoming merely administratively compliant and focus on increasing overall cyber resilience.

A key outcome will be the ability to determine the level of maturity a department is at and increasing visibility into their own cyber security posture and the strategies involved in developing a roadmap for achieving the desired security posture. This approach to remediation involves leveraging the ecosystem of people, processes and emerging technologies to gain compliance, confidence and resilience along with fusing security into the entire department operating model.

As a partner of the Federal Government's Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC) and a member of the Defence Industry Security Program (DISP), ASG Group is provided with continuous threat intelligence which allows us to stay continuously at the leading edge of current security programs and best practices.

Dr Alex Antic

On-demand

Australian National University

Alex has experience across several industries and domains, including federal and state government, insurance, asset management, banking, consulting, and academia. He has expertise in leveraging data science and AI to deliver impact and change by developing and managing high-performance teams, and through strategic advisory and technical expertise. The Institute of Analytics Professionals of Australia recently recognised him as one of the Top 10 Analytics Leaders in Australia.

Success in the APS - the science of change

This talk details how government agencies and departments can leverage data, emerging technology, and the right culture to develop a successful, sustainable, and scalable data science, and artificial intelligence capability.

Chloe White

On-demand

Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources

Chloe is the Australian Government's National Blockchain Roadmap Lead, responsible for driving the day-to-day implementation of Australia's first whole-of-government blockchain policy strategy. Before this, she was the lead blockchain policy advisor at the Treasury where she led the review into initial coin offerings, advised on blockchain in finance, and was the Department's standing representative at the Council of Financial Regulators DLT Working Group. She has completed postgraduate studies in public policy at the United Nations University and holds an undergraduate degree in economics and finance from UNSW.

Blockchain: does it deserve a second chance?

Chloe will be busting common myths and misconceptions about blockchain and provide examples of how blockchain has become more efficient, private and value-adding since the peak of blockchain's hype cycle around 2017 and 2018.

Awards presenters

Elanor Huntington

Awards presenter

Dean of Engineering and Computer Science, Australian National University

Elanor is Dean of the College of Engineering and Computer Science at the Australian National University (ANU). She is an established senior academic leader, with Board appointments to Innovation Science Australia, Significant Capital Ventures, Questacon and other government scientific advisory roles. In 2017 she was named an honorary Fellow of Engineers Australia and led the extended Group of Eight (Go8+) Engineering Deans as the first female Chair until 2019. Before she joined the ANU, she was Head of Engineering and IT at University of New South Wales (UNSW). During this time, she helped bring about significant transformation within the School, including setting up UNSW Space and The Australian Centre for Cyber Security. In 2000, she completed her PhD in experimental Quantum Optics at the ANU. Her current research includes the control of quantum systems, and more specifically the interface between theory and applications. In 2009, she completed a Masters of Information Technology, also through the ANU. She was recently selected to provide expert advice to the newly established Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence. In 2017 she delivered a TEDxSydney Talk on 'Why we need Engineers now more than ever' and later in 2019, co-founded the Engineering for Australia Taskforce to provide expert advice on addressing barriers to women's participation in university engineering programs. As Dean, Elanor does more than contemplate the difference between distinctions and high distinctions. Her innovative thinking has recast engineering and computer science at the ANU with an unprecedented investment to reimagine the way we do things.

Ron Gauci

Awards presenter

CEO, Australian Information Industry Association (AIIA)

Ron is the CEO of the AIIA. He is known as the 'go-to' executive and has a track record of delivering significant growth, business transformation, good governance, asset leverage, and quality leadership. He is recognised as an inspirational leader with a reputation for getting the best out of his teams and getting things done. Ron has an innate ability to guide organisations to realise their potential. He has held various leadership roles in both public and private organisations.

Stephanie Foster PSM

Awards presenter

Deputy Secretary, Governance and APS Reform, Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM&C)

Stephanie joined PM&C in December 2017, bringing more than 30 years' public sector experience to the role. Stephanie's role sees her take a 'whole picture' outlook to deliver results on behalf of the Federal Government and Australian people. She is responsible for Cabinet and coordinating support for the Prime Minister, machinery of government, legal policy, and governance issues, as well as the Department's corporate management.
